description: Alteration of earlier waniand, from Middle English waniand (“waning”), present participle of wanien (“to wane”) (from the phrase "in the waniand [moon]", i.e. in the time of the waning moon, in an unlucky period).

examples: S’foote what are these that pynch me? Goblins?
A wanion on the Elues for me  […]

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Vengeance (in the phrases in a wanion, with a wanion, “with a vengeance”).
examples: And yet notwithstanding we must haue these goodly pageants played vpon the sabaoth day (in a wanion) because there are no mo daies in the week.
